â  
'''Stephen John Nash''', [[Order of Canada|OC]], [[Order of British Columbia|OBC]] (born 7 February 1974),<ref>[http://www.gg.ca/media/doc.asp?lang=e&DocID=5252 Governor General Announces New Appointments to the Order of Canada], gg.ca, accessed 9 March 2008.</ref><ref>[http://www.protocol.gov.bc.ca/protocol/news/BG-2006_OBC.pdf Stephen John Nash], protocol.gov.bc.ca, accessed 9 March 2008.</ref><ref name="foundation">[http://www.stevenash.org/html/about.html About Steve], stevenash.org, accessed 20 February 2008.</ref> is a [[Canada|Canadian]] professional [[basketball]] player who plays [[point guard]] for the [[Phoenix Suns]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA). Nash, who was born in [[South Africa]] but grew up in Canada, enjoyed a successful [[high-school]] basketball career, and he was eventually given a scholarship by [[Santa Clara Broncos#Men's basketball|Santa Clara University]]. In his four seasons with the Broncos, the team made three [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Tournament]] appearances, and Nash was twice named the [[West Coast Conference]] Player of the Year.
'''Stephen John Nash''', [[Order of Canada|OC]], [[Order of British Columbia|OBC]] (born 7 February 1974),<ref>[http://www.gg.ca/media/doc.asp?lang=e&DocID=5252 Governor General Announces New Appointments to the Order of Canada], gg.ca, accessed 9 March 2008.</ref><ref>[http://www.protocol.gov.bc.ca/protocol/news/BG-2006_OBC.pdf Stephen John Nash], protocol.gov.bc.ca, accessed 9 March 2008.</ref><ref name="foundation">[http://www.stevenash.org/html/about.html About Steve], stevenash.org, accessed 20 February 2008.</ref> is a [[Canada|Canadian]] professional [[basketball]] player who plays [[point guard]] for the [[Phoenix Suns]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA). Nash, who was born in [[South Africa]] but grew up in Canada, enjoyed a successful [[high-school]] basketball career, and he was eventually given a scholarship by [[Santa Clara Broncos#Men's basketball|Santa Clara University]]. In his four seasons with the Broncos, the team made three [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Tournament]] appearances, and Nash was twice named the [[West Coast Conference]] Player of the Year.
After graduating from Santa Clara as the team's all-time leader in [[assist (basketball)|assists]], he entered the [[1996 NBA Draft]] and was selected as the 15th pick by the Phoenix Suns. He made a minimal impact, and was traded to the [[Dallas Mavericks]] in 1998. By his third season with the Mavericks, he was voted into his first [[NBA All-Star Game]] and had earned his first [[All-NBA]] selection. Together with [[Dirk Nowitzki]] and [[Michael Finley]], Nash led the Mavericks to the [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] Finals the [[2002â03 NBA season|following season]]. However, he became a [[free agent]] after the {{nbay|2003|app=season}} and returned to the Phoenix Suns.
After graduating from Santa Clara as the team's all-time leader in [[assist (basketball)|assists]], he entered the [[1996 NBA Draft]] and was selected as the 15th pick by the Phoenix Suns. He made a minimal impact, and was traded to the [[Dallas Mavericks]] in 1998. By his third season with the Mavericks, he was voted into his first [[NBA All-Star Game]] and had earned his first [[All-NBA]] selection. Together with [[Dirk Nowitzki]] and [[Michael Finley]], Nash led the Mavericks to the [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] Finals the [[2002â03 NBA season|following season]]. However, he became a [[free agent]] after the {{nbay|2003|app=season}} and returned to the Phoenix Suns.
â   â
He is the whitest player in the world as he is the best 3 point shooter and also gets a lot of assists.
 
In the {{nbay|2004|app=season}}, Nash led the Suns to the Western Conference Finals, and was named [[NBA MVP|the league's Most Valuable Player]] (MVP). He was named MVP again in the {{nbay|2005|app=season}}, and missed out on a third consecutive MVP title to Nowitzki [[2006â07 NBA season|the next season]]. Named by [[ESPN]] in 2006 as the ninth greatest point guard of all time, Nash has led the league in assists and [[free-throw]] percentage at various points in his career. He is also ranked as one of the top players in league history for [[three-point field goal|three-point shooting]], free-throw shooting, total assists and assists per game.
In the {{nbay|2004|app=season}}, Nash led the Suns to the Western Conference Finals, and was named [[NBA MVP|the league's Most Valuable Player]] (MVP). He was named MVP again in the {{nbay|2005|app=season}}, and missed out on a third consecutive MVP title to Nowitzki [[2006â07 NBA season|the next season]]. Named by [[ESPN]] in 2006 as the ninth greatest point guard of all time, Nash has led the league in assists and [[free-throw]] percentage at various points in his career. He is also ranked as one of the top players in league history for [[three-point field goal|three-point shooting]], free-throw shooting, total assists and assists per game.
